The mathematical foundations of quantum mechanics are a major topic of current research. The most promising approach is to use the language of category theory, which has been successfully applied to classical mechanics. However, the mathematical foundations of quantum mechanics are still an open problem. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to quantum mechanics. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are thought to have evolved from free-living cnidarians. To understand the origin of the parasitic lifestyle, we compared the genomes of two myxozoans to the genome of a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals, and that the parasites are a sister taxon to the less reduced cnidarian parasite. The parasites are also characterized by a reduction in gene content and expression of signaling pathways and transcriptional factors important for development. These results suggest that the parasitic lifestyle was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. This is the first time that a taxonomic sampling that represents the breadth of myxozoan diversity has been used to infer the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host antiviral responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral action of IFN and may help to design new strategies to combat the ongoing pandemic. (Show more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels.

Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. Here, we quantify the impact of climate change on maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of species-level identification of plant remains in traditional studies. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that, despite being similar in body size and digestive physiology, these species differed in their proportional grass consumption, and that dietary overlap was greatest between species that were dissimilar in these ways. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the US economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act loans, which are based on debt. Our results suggest that the government should consider grants rather than debt for these loans.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. Using data from the Malaspina 2010 circumnavigation, regional surveys, and previously published reports, we show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of floating plastic debris, which points at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in humans, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising therapeutic candidate for MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cell clusters that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is critical for the endothelium to control vascular function, but the nature of the communication network has been poorly understood. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells. The findings provide a framework for understanding the endothelium’s control of cardiovascular activity. This work also provides a foundation for understanding the communication network in other cell types and tissues. The findings have implications for understanding the communication network in the brain and other tissues. The COVID-19 pandemic has presented enormous data challenges. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to provide open access to data that can be used to monitor the pandemic and inform public health policy. The API provides data on COVID-19 cases, deaths, and hospitalizations, as well as many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the API will be useful to researchers, policymakers, and the public. The code and data are available at https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-api.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a key residue that is involved in this allosteric communication. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be used as a structural switch to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. It also opens the way for the development of new pharmacological tools for the control of these important ion channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in human health and disease is only beginning to be understood, and the potential of the microbiome to produce natural products is just beginning to be explored. This study provides a resource of anaerobic gut fungi that can be used to investigate the potential of the gut microbiome to produce natural products.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is still unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait, directly influences social dominance in rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The ability to design and fabricate multifunctional mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures, which seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors, some of which are unachievable by a single material. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design multifunctional mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of humans. The hemoglobin levels in the blood are controlled by the expression of the globin genes. The globin genes are expressed in a developmental manner, with fetal hemoglobin being expressed in the fetus and newborn and adult hemoglobin being expressed in the adult. The expression of fetal hemoglobin is controlled by the transcription factor BCL11A. Here we show that the mRNA-binding protein IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the developmental expression of fetal hemoglobin.

Cancer is the second leading cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of new therapies, the survival rate of cancer patients remains low. In this study, we found that the activation of PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we discovered that SREBP1-mediated induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1) plays a critical role in the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1. These findings suggest that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease and the leading cause of heart failure. The major drug class for treating hypertension is L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are associated with an increased risk of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate a Ca2+ signaling pathway that promotes vascular remodeling. Our findings have implications for the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of Ca2+ signaling proteins are elevated.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird species, but that the policy was insufficient to reverse the decline of older forests. We also show that the creation of early-seral ecosystems on federal land has not impeded the development of older-forest structure. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our findings also highlight the importance of monitoring the effects of forest management policies over time. (Less)

The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the medical community. The present work presents a computational approach to design new antibiotics, which is based on the prediction of the most important properties of the compounds. The design strategy is tested by the development of acylide antibiotics, which are a promising class of antibiotics. The design strategy is validated by the development of new compounds, which are more active than telithromycin, and which are more soluble and more permeable to the cell membrane. The design strategy is further validated by the in vivo activity of the designed compounds against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The design strategy is expected to be useful for the development of new antibiotics.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the network on large datasets, and also makes it difficult to apply the network to new problems. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and that consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of these devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and reduces the next-morning alertness. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Earth sciences, but the cause of the cooling is still debated. One of the most popular hypotheses is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB samples is consistent with a terrestrial origin, and the spherules from Pennsylvania are consistent with their source being in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the YDB cooling. (Show more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but that its function is dependent on the stage of development.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species, and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Our results show that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of insect diversity and the evolution of plant cell walls. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the size of the cumulative artifact than for the CCE of the population. This may be because the size of the cumulative artifact is determined by the number of individuals in the population, whereas the CCE of the population is determined by the number of generations. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the evolution of culture. They also have implications for the design of evolutionary experiments. Finally, our results have implications for the design of evolutionary psychology experiments.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is highly correlated with AD risk, and APOE4 is the most strongly associated isoform. APOE is also highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain, and is involved in normal synapse pruning and turnover. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies also provide a potential therapeutic target for AD treatment.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the size of a small country. It is the densest part of the planet, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3, and is the only part of the planet that is not molten. The inner core is a mystery because it is not known how it formed. The most widely accepted theory is that it formed by the solidification of the core material, which is a mixture of iron and nickel, at the center of the Earth. However, this theory has a problem: the required degree of undercooling is too high to be achieved by the core material. We show that the solidification of the core material is not the first step of the formation of the inner core, but rather the second step. This solves the inner core nucleation paradox and provides a key factor in understanding the formation of the inner core. This work also provides a new perspective on the solidification of the Earth.

The brain’s reactivity to dopamine (DA) stimulation is a key determinant of the subjective effects of drugs of abuse and addiction. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular DA, is blunted in marijuana abusers, who are more likely to have addiction. The blunted reactivity to MP in marijuana abusers is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and understanding how the human brain processes language is a major goal of cognitive science. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural network models for natural language processing also predict the brain’s response to language in humans. This provides computational evidence that predictive processing is a fundamental mechanism of language comprehension in the human brain. The models’ neural fits are correlated with their predictive accuracy, suggesting that the brain’s predictive representation of language is shaped by the predictive structure of the language we speak. These results have implications for understanding the brain’s representation of language in health and disease.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in the last few years, but it is still in its infancy. It is now time to start thinking about its limitations and how to overcome them. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of neural networks with great approximation qualities, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a neural network. This is a first step toward understanding the limits of neural networks and how to overcome them.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the pharmaceutical industry to develop a vaccine quickly enough, and the failure of the public to comply with public health measures. In this paper, we argue that the failure of the public to comply with public health measures is also due to a failure of science communication. We present a classic psychological experiment that shows that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We argue that this failure of science communication is a major reason why people do not comply with public health measures. We conclude with a call for a more scientific approach to science communication.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and the cause of the disease has been debated for centuries. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient from Mexico, and compared it with that of the leprosy pathogen Mycobacterium leprae. We found that the two pathogens are remarkably conserved, and that they are still able to cause similar diseases. This study also provides a phylogeographic survey of the distribution of the leprosy pathogen, and suggests that the two pathogens have been in existence for a long time. The study also provides a resource for future studies of the pathogenesis of leprosy. (Show more)

The emergence of thermodynamics from quantum mechanics is one of the most fundamental and intriguing questions in physics. The entanglement dynamics is a key ingredient in this process, as it is the source of the statistical ensemble that describes the system at long times. However, the entanglement dynamics is a nonperturbative problem, which is hard to solve exactly. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be computed exactly for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. This allows us to unveil the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit for arbitrary initial states. Our result is a step toward the understanding of the entanglement dynamics in general isolated quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives and has caused enormous economic and social disruption. The only vaccine currently available is based on the inactivated virus, which is not suitable for mass vaccination. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, which is being developed by our group. The vaccine candidate is based on recoding the viral genome with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate induces high levels of neutralizing antibodies and is protective in hamsters. This vaccine candidate has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which was able to fit mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human mortality data in the study of past epidemics.

The evolution of brain size has been a major topic of debate for more than a century. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is still poorly understood. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only dependent on brain size but also on the number of neurons. This study provides a more comprehensive picture of the evolution of brain information-processing capacity across amniotes. It also provides a more accurate picture of the evolution of brain size in reptiles, which is important for understanding the evolution of cognition in reptiles. The role of TRAP1 in cancer is controversial. Some studies suggest that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others suggest that it is an oncoprotein. Here we show that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator that promotes a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis, and that this switch is important for the invasiveness of cancer cells. These findings suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal component in almost all cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The disassembly process is regulated by a family of proteins that are named actin depolymerizing factors (ADF)/cofilins. These proteins are involved in many cellular processes, such as cell migration and cytokinesis. The mechanism by which ADF/cofilins disassemble actin filaments is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilins can induce a mechanical torque on the filaments, which enhances the disassembly process. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical for cells to disassemble highly connected filament networks, such as those found in the cortex. Our results provide a mechanism for how cells can efficiently disassemble filament networks, which are essential for cell migration and cytokinesis.

The food industry has long promoted the use of sweeteners such as fructose, which are sweeter than glucose, to increase the appeal of foods and beverages. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically studied. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and related disorders.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian ancestries, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar, and it has implications for the settlement of the Indian Ocean islands. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which people’s emotions are transferred from one person to another. We show that this occurs even when people are not interacting in person, and even when they are not aware of the emotions being transferred. This work suggests that in-person interaction is not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media, and for our understanding of the role of emotions in social networks. They also suggest that people’s emotions are more malleable than previously thought.

The ribosome is a complex machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. The mRNA sequence is translated into a protein sequence, and the protein can then perform a variety of functions. One of the most common modifications found in mRNA coding regions is pseudouridine (Ψ), which is thought to play a role in translation. We show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a modest effect on translation, and that this effect can be observed in a reconstituted translation system as well as human cells. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This is an important finding because it suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a significant impact on the translation of the protein encoded by that mRNA. This finding has implications for understanding how mRNA modifications can impact protein synthesis and for developing new strategies for controlling protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a range of potential confounders, and they are not driven by factors such as depressive symptoms or prosperity. The feeling that life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. (PsycINFO Database Record

The common cold is the most common viral infection in the world, and rhinoviruses are the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a more favorable cellular environment for viral replication at cool temperature. However, the molecular basis for this phenomenon has remained unclear. Here, we show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at cool temperature if they are primed to produce less antiviral defense response and less type I interferon. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication and may have implications for the development of antiviral strategies for the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria sense their environment using a variety of sensory systems. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This mechanosensory system is based on the type IV pili, a major surface adhesin, and is mediated by the Chp chemosensory system. The system is activated by the mechanical activity of pili, which leads to the stimulation of the Chp system and the activation of a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term surface attachment and stimulates additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing provides a new perspective on the evolution of bacterial sensory systems. It also demonstrates that type IV pili are not only involved in twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This study thus contributes to our understanding of the evolution of bacterial sensory systems and their role in the regulation of virulence. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the resulting contamination of surface waters is a major concern. However, the extent of pesticide contamination of surface waters remains poorly understood because of a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a comprehensive metaanalysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters and the risk of pesticide contamination to aquatic biodiversity. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the long-term persistence of the virus in animal reservoirs is a major concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a better understanding of the role of wildlife in the pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the problems and solutions for the future of hydropower. We find that the industry has been overestimating the benefits and underestimating the costs of dams. We also find that the industry has been overestimating the benefits of dams and underestimating the costs of climate change. We propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources. We believe that the solutions we propose will help the industry move toward sustainable practices and help the world to achieve the Paris Agreement.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still controversial. Here, we show that Aβ is not the only factor that triggers an inflammatory response in AD. We demonstrate that soluble Aβ species are not the only toxic species, but also oligomeric Aβ is responsible for the activation of immune cells. Moreover, we show that the accumulation of oligomeric Aβ in vulnerable brain regions precedes the formation of Aβ plaques. Thus, we propose that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This finding has important implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD.

The domestication of chickens (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in human history. However, the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens remains elusive. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of more than 10,000 animal bones from 234 archaeological sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. Our results show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread in the Southern Levant during the Hellenistic period (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.). This finding is supported further by a survey of the earliest European sites, which show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the history of chickens and their integration into the economy of the ancient world. (

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. The method is based on the use of a short sequence of amino acids that is added to the protein at various times during folding. The protein is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. The method allows the study of the folding of a protein at the level of its structure. We have applied the method to the folding of the maltose binding protein. The results show that the folding of the protein involves distinct native-like intermediates in distinct steps. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct steps. This is a significant advance in our understanding of protein folding. (Show more)

The cellular concentration of dinucleoside tetraphosphates increases in response to stress, and their cellular levels are maintained at high levels by the action of a family of enzymes. In this study, we show that one of these enzymes, a pyrophosphohydrolase, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing stress, and that it prefers to remove the cap of Np4-capped RNAs over the caps of their tri- and diphosphorylated counterparts. This unique manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of the enzyme positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The development of severe sepsis is characterized by a sustained immune dysfunction, which is associated with the expansion of immunosuppressive cells such as myeloid-derived suppressor cells and regulatory T cells. In this study, we demonstrate that the administration of citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The use of citrulline as a therapeutic strategy could be a promising approach to improve the clinical outcome of sepsis patients. View Full-Text

The biomass of the biosphere is the main component of the global carbon cycle and is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are key for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time toward a critical state, in which the rate of change of the system’s activity is equal to a critical value. SOC systems are characterized by the presence of a power-law distribution of activity rates, and by the absence of external control. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the classical sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a material with a high sensitivity to external stimuli, such as pressure, light, and electric field. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be completely closed. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its electronic bandgap can be opened, by applying electric field. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The study of the antifungal activity of NCR peptides is limited by the lack of structural information. Here, we report the solution structure of the 36-amino acid NCR044 peptide, which is largely disordered and exhibits a unique structure with one α-helix and one β-sheet. The peptide exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, and it was able to bind to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides. The peptide was able to penetrate the cell wall and cell membrane of germlings, and induce reactive oxygen species. The peptide was able to bind to the cell wall of the fungal pathogen, and was able to penetrate the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. The results suggest that the peptide is able to disrupt the integrity of the fungal cell wall and membrane, and induce cell death. The results also suggest that the peptide is able to bind to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides, and that this binding is important for the antifungal activity of the peptide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the life history of sperm is intimately connected to the female reproductive tract. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome is profoundly affected by the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins are enriched in the sperm proteome after mating and that they support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a critical component of the blood’s clotting system. It binds to the platelet surface protein glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) to form a complex that delivers clotting factors to the site of injury. The binding of VWF to GPIbα is triggered by flow, and the binding reaction is critical for the delivery of clotting factors to the site of injury. We show that the binding reaction can be switched on by force, and that this force-induced switching is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a common disorder of the blood’s clotting system.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that interact with humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a database for the human virome, which is the largest and most diverse database of its kind. The database is used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study provide a foundation for future research on the human virome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past can be inferred from the isotopic composition of marine cherts, but this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with NDK thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the nervous system. The pore gate of an ion channel is the main site of ion flow and is responsible for channel activation and deactivation. The selectivity filter is the site of slow inactivation and recovery. We found that the K+ channel BK has two distinct gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The two gates are spatially overlapped or coexisting at the selectivity filter. C-type inactivation in BK channels is state-dependent and is closed state-dependent. The rates of C-type inactivation and recovery are inversely correlated with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Show more)

The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate infection. Here, we show that the malaria parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen, EBA175, alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work also provides a new approach to the study of malaria parasite invasion, which could be applied to other parasite–host cell interactions. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a material with a high sensitivity to external stimuli, such as pressure, light, and electric field. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, without phonon instability, by applying a small strain. We also show that the bandgap of diamond can be tuned reversibly by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The impact of humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection is controversial. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice deficient in caspase-1/11, an enzyme involved in host defense against influenza virus infection. These results indicate that low humidity impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on the severity of influenza virus infection. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and sentences at the top. But how the brain builds such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This view of language processing has implications for the design of artificial intelligence systems and for the treatment of language disorders.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in development and homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the pathway. This is a unique feature that is not commonly found in other redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we present a characterization of the brain circuit that promotes overeating in mice. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. We also show that this circuit is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and dopamine neurons in the midbrain, near the locus coeruleus. This circuit is not involved in the hunger or satiety mechanisms that govern normal feeding. Thus, we present a characterization of a circuit that may contribute to obesity. This circuit may be a target for the development of new treatments for obesity. (Show more)

The ability of plants to fix atmospheric nitrogen is essential for the sustainability of agriculture, but the supply of nitrogen is limited by the amount of fixed nitrogen available to the plant. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would therefore be a powerful tool for the sustainable improvement of crop productivity. Here, we describe the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of diazotroph gene expression. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the field of synthetic biology and on the development of sustainable agriculture. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major driver of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, the early alerts generated by these systems rarely reach the most directly affected populations in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which is better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that the climate and health benefits of reducing air pollution are much larger than previously estimated. We also show that the climate and health benefits of reducing air pollution are larger than the climate and health costs of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions. This suggests that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed over 2 million lives worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) are still waiting for their first shipment. The development of a cost-effective vaccine for LMICs is critical to ending the pandemic. Here we report the design and characterization of a recombinant protein vaccine candidate that can be produced at large scale, is highly immunogenic, and can be used to develop a VLP vaccine. This vaccine candidate can be used to develop a vaccine for multiple variants of concern, and can be manufactured in low-cost, low-resource settings.

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is involved in the development of many tissues and is implicated in the pathogenesis of several human cancers. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs (DrALKs) are activated by secreted ligands and that this activation is required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. Our results provide evidence that the ALK family of RTKs is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues and suggest that the secreted ligands of the ALKALs may have evolved as a mechanism to regulate the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This study provides insights into the evolution of the ALK family of RTKs and the role of secreted ligands in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. These findings may also have implications for the development of targeted therapies for neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex and poorly understood process. The study of ancient genomes has revealed that plague was a relatively recent zoonosis, but the details of its early evolution and ecology are still unknown. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its evolution. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia, rapid dispersal across continents, and a stepwise pattern of gene loss. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, which will be useful for understanding the origins of this devastating disease. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election. (PsycInfo Database Record

The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands is a major driver of climate change. The management of annual cropping systems on North American Mollisols has led to the release of massive amounts of carbon (C) to the atmosphere. We show that the management of perennial pastures and annual cropping systems with reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations, and manure addition can sequester more C in the soil. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to mitigate climate change and support the transition to climate-smart agriculture. This work also highlights the importance of long-term field experiments in understanding the complex interactions between management, soil, and climate. (Show more)

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a risk assessment framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a scientific basis for prioritizing research and public health interventions to prevent future outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals, but the mechanisms that underlie the production of this reward are poorly understood. We show that the red color of Nesocodon mauritianus nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a similar red nectar in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work suggests that the red nectar trait is a convergently evolved adaptation to attract pollinators, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid for the chemical biodiversity database. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 450 and 650 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. The analysis of functional variants also indicates that the genetic history of Europe is not only shaped by migrations, but also by natural selection. Our results have implications for our understanding of the genetic history of Europe and the evolution of human traits.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5 were investigated. The results suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are dependent on the host species. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. These findings provide insights into the origin of MERS-CoV and the evolution of bat coronaviruses. They also provide a basis for the development of a vaccine and antiviral drugs against MERS-CoV. These findings are of great significance for the prevention and control of MERS-CoV. (Show more)

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a periurban population in Cambodia. This approach is feasible and reveals a diverse pathogen landscape, underscoring the need for ongoing pathogen surveillance. DNA replication is a fundamental process that is essential for the survival of all organisms. The lagging strand of the DNA double helix is synthesized in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells and is responsible for the synthesis of the Okazaki fragments of the lagging strand of the linear genome. The process of lagging strand synthesis is highly complex and requires the cooperation of multiple proteins. In this study, we have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the human DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) holoenzyme. Our results indicate that pol δ maintains a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the dynamics of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for the process of lagging strand synthesis. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the present work, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules from an RNA template. This polymerase can also synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers and ribozymes. Furthermore, the polymerase can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a significant step toward the reconstruction of life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab is evaluated. The results show that tocilizumab is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, which can reduce mortality and improve the clinical condition of patients.

The role of metal micronutrients in the growth and development of fungi is well established, but the existence of natural products that bind and regulate metal homeostasis in fungi is less well known. Here we describe the existence of a natural product biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of this cluster in other filamentous fungi suggests a role for these natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the interaction of fungi with competing microbes. This work provides a new perspective on the role of natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the interactions of fungi with other microbes. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is significant because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is not stable at present-day conditions. The presence of this mineral in a sedimentary deposit is consistent with the presence of a silicic volcanic source in the sediment source region. The presence of a silicic volcanic source in the sediment source region is consistent with the presence of silicic volcanic features in the vicinity of the sedimentary deposit. The presence of a silicic volcanic source in the sediment source region is also consistent with the presence of silicic volcanic features in the entire northern hemisphere of Mars. The presence of a silicic volcanic source in the sediment source region is also consistent with the presence of silicic volcanic features in the entire southern hemisphere of Mars.

Frost is a major abiotic stress that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. Here, we analyze the geographic distribution of late-spring frosts and the resistance strategies of woody species to infer trees’ adaptations for minimizing frost damage to their leaves. We find that trees in regions that are currently exposed to late-spring frosts are likely to be exposed to increasing frost damage in the future. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of these cells are not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains a Th17 phenotype and the other of which transitions to a Th1-like phenotype. These two subsets are required for the development of colitis, and the Th17 cell subset that retains a Th17 phenotype is required for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Furthermore, they indicate that the development of Th17 cells is dependent on the expression of both the IL-12 and IFN-γ receptors. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in several genes, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and test potential treatments. This method will also enable rapid production of motor neuron-like cells from healthy donors, which can be used to study normal motor neuron development and function. This will lead to a better understanding of the disease and the development of new treatments.

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a major factor in the pathogenesis of many diseases. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the vector. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the vector microbiota and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases.
