The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. However, the diversity of early branching pygostylians is limited, obscuring our understanding of the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases the known diversity of early pygostylians and adds important information about the origin of the modern avian tail.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without understanding the behavior of the components of the climate system. In this paper, we show that the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

The evolution of vertebrate coloration is one of the most important topics in biology. However, the biochemical basis, biology, and evolution of chlorosis are poorly understood. Here, we show that the occurrence of high biliverdin in anurans has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of serpin family proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of vertebrate coloration. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. The identification of factors that regulate the breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype is therefore of great importance. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn regulates the BCSC phenotype. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was a major innovation in the history of book production. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum

The intestinal epithelium is the first line of defense against pathogens and environmental toxins. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our results suggest that RORα/HDAC3-mediated epigenetic regulation of NF-κB signaling could be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most prevalent substitution in circulating variants, and it is hypothesized to increase infectivity. Here, we show that the D614G mutation leads to a range of more open conformations of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion. These results provide insights into the mechanism of action of the D614G mutation and may help to design vaccines and therapeutics that are more effective against the current and future variants. COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. The chemical properties of matter are the basis of chemistry, and they are the key to understanding the origin of the diversity of the chemical world. The chemical properties of matter are also the key to understanding the origin of the diversity of the physical world, as they are the origin of the properties of matter in the universe. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of matter change under pressure, and that these changes are consistent with the origin of the diversity of the physical world.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency of extreme fire events, which can have large impacts on the carbon cycle. However, the role of human ignitions and fire suppression in modulating fire activity is poorly understood. Here, we show that changes in human demography can have a large effect on fire activity, which can offset some of the warming caused by climate change. Our results highlight the importance of human ignitions in modulating fire activity and the need to consider the role of fire suppression in climate models. This study also highlights the need to consider the role of human ignitions in climate models, as they can have a large effect on fire activity, which can offset some of the warming caused by climate change.

The gut microbiota is a major component of the animal body, and its composition is known to be important for the health of the host. However, the mechanisms by which the host regulates the composition of the microbiota are not well understood. Here, we show that the host animal regulates the composition of the microbiota through the provision of a single nutrient, chitin, which is catabolized by the microbiota. This regulation is specific to the host and the microbiota, and it is only effective when the host is mature. This work provides a new perspective on the regulation of the gut microbiota, and it suggests that other hosts may regulate the composition of their gut microbiota through the provision of specific nutrients. This work also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the gut microbiota. (Show more)

The study of topics in text data is a central problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method that integrates advances in theoretical machine learning with word embedding to model topics in text. Our method, discourse atom topic modeling, is motivated by the need to understand the content of text data from many domains. We apply our method to the National Violent Death Reporting System, a unique source of text data on violent death. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. It can be applied to any domain of text data, and can be extended to other types of models. Our method can also be used to identify gender biases in word embeddings. Our results provide a starting point for further research on gender biases in word embeddings.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of the Black Death in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents. Here, we show that the Black Death was the consequence of repeated introductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. We provide evidence for the existence of no permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results challenge the current paradigm of the second plague pandemic and suggest that the introduction of the disease into Europe was a recurrent event. This has implications for our understanding of the spread of the disease and the development of the Black Death in Europe. (Less)

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases of marine invertebrates. The disease is caused by a densovirus that has spread rapidly across the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans. Here, we show that the virus is also responsible for a recent outbreak of wasting disease on the Pacific coast of North America. We also show that the virus has been present in the region for at least 72 y. This finding has important implications for the management of the disease, as well as for the conservation of these iconic animals.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML is poor. The identification of targets for treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We also show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. Furthermore, we demonstrate that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can be used to treat AML. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also provide a proof of principle for the use of antibodies capable of blocking IL-1 signaling as a treatment for other diseases.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar, and they have implications for the study of human migrations and the evolution of human diversity. (Show more)

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to convert the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used in quantitative analyses. We also show how to use this information to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the Crop Condition Index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results have implications for the management of agricultural production, and for the development of new systems for monitoring the status of crops.

Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the adaptive modulation of neuronal firing rates. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the evolution of life. It is also one of the most challenging problems in biology, because it is difficult to observe and to model. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a key step in the transition to heterotrophy, is linked to a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on plastid genes. Our findings have implications for the evolution of plastid genes and their functional complexes, as well as for the evolution of the transition to heterotrophy.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is expected to be of interest to the general public, climate scientists, and policymakers.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the first nuclear test explosion, is of great historical significance. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, is of great scientific interest because of its composition and its age. The age of the trinitite is known to within a few hours, and the age of the quasicrystal is known to within a few minutes. This discovery provides a unique window into the history of the material and the conditions under which it was formed. The discovery of this new quasicrystal also provides a new material for study, and the study of this material will provide insights into the nature of quasicrystals and the conditions under which they form.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase reaction,” has remained a major challenge for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. Here we show that the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring is catalyzed by three classes of enzymes in oxygenic phototrophs, and that their evolution is linked to the evolution of photosynthesis. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the cyclase reaction. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). These findings suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes and microglia/macrophages may be promising therapeutic targets for reducing neuroinflammation.

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest period in the state’s instrumental record and is now considered an exceptional event. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions that are associated with acute human and ecosystem impacts. This finding has important implications for climate adaptation and mitigation planning in California and other regions that are experiencing or are likely to experience increasing drought risk. It also suggests that the probability of drought will continue to increase in the future.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. The news media are a critical source of information for the public, and the content of news coverage is likely to have a significant impact on public opinion. This work reports on a large-scale, cross-national experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that people around the world do, in fact, react more strongly to negative news content, and that this negativity bias is present in both Anglo-American and non-Anglo-American samples. The results also show that individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is substantial, and that this variation is not explained by demographic or political characteristics. These findings have implications for the content of news coverage, and for the way in which news is consumed around the world. They also suggest that the conventional wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads” may be outdated.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, but its physiological role has remained elusive. Here, we show that loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. We also identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 that cause Stormorken syndrome, a rare disease with hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise due to climate change, which is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This rate is 10 times smaller than the rate of sea level rise due to natural causes, such as the expansion and melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets. Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral replication that has shown efficacy in animal models of SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV. Here, we show that remdesivir is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection, and that it can be used both prophylactically and therapeutically. These data support the development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The gut microbiota is a major component of the animal body, and the symbionts that reside in the epithelium are critical for host health. In this study, we show that the host provides a single glycan to its symbiont at a specific time of day, and that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and for the host–symbiont metabolic interactions that are critical for the health of the symbiont. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of the gut microbiota, and it suggests that other hosts may similarly regulate the activities of their gut microbial communities through the strategic provision of specific nutrients, whose catabolism modulates conditions like pH or anoxia in their symbionts’ habitat. (Show more)

The suspension rate in US schools is the highest among any industrialized nation. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline, which in turn can reduce suspension rates. This is a scalable intervention that can be implemented in schools and may help to reduce the suspension rate in the United States.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this work, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on the transcriptional fidelity of RNA polymerase II. We found that the minor-groove alkylation of DNA can lead to transcriptional stalling, and the major-groove alkylation can lead to the formation of multiple transcriptional bypass routes. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis and transcriptional stalling. This work also provides a foundation for the development of novel therapeutic strategies to combat the impact of DNA alkylation on the accuracy of DNA replication and transcription.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, precleaved MERS viruses used receptor-proximal, cell-surface proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry, whereas uncleaved MERS viruses trafficked past these cell-surface proteases and into endosomes.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large influence on these emissions, and the food system is the largest contributor to greenhouse gas emissions in the UK. The food choices of the population can also have a large impact on population health. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria by 50% increased the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 40%. This increase in vegetarian meals was sustained over the course of the year. These results provide evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. They also provide evidence that nudging meal selection by increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can be effective. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in a wide range of settings.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment, and is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we apply a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We also find that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion by oncogenes, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggests possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work also provides a resource for the breast cancer community to identify surface targets for drug discovery. (Show more)

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid understanding of the molecular basis of the disease. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV. This structure provides a molecular basis for the unique immune evasion and evasion of the host antiviral response observed in SARS-CoV-2. The structure also provides a basis for the development of future therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapies for this potentially life-threatening condition. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in the context of big data and complex statistical modeling. The challenge is to assess the strength of associations that we find in our data, given that we have “cherry-picked” them. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a better understanding of the strengths and limitations of these methods. The hope is that this will lead to better statistical practice.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains unknown. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone induces EC development from human adult skin fibroblasts. This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. Furthermore, ETV2-induced EC development provides a new therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders and the regeneration of organs. Our study also provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This approach can be applied to the treatment of ischemic disorders and the regeneration of organs. (Show more)

The discovery of the ligand for anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has led to the identification of a third ligand, augmentor, which is also a ligand for Ltk. We show that augmentor is essential for iridophore differentiation in zebrafish. This process is mediated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a new perspective on the role of RTKs in development and disease. It also provides a new target for the treatment of anaplastic large cell lymphoma and other diseases mediated by Alk and Ltk.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING plays a critical role in the regulation of insulin secretion in β-cells. STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which was associated with the loss of nuclear translocation of Pax6. These findings provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D.

The influenza A virus is a single-stranded RNA virus that infects birds and humans. It is responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is composed of eight segments of single-stranded RNA, which are packaged into the viral particles. The packaging of the viral genome is a complex process, which is still not fully understood. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which is required for the selective packaging of the influenza A virus. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process involving a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the disturbed flow-induced activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerosis and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of athero-protective drugs. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but the economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. (Less)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which is absent in insects. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of insect–plant interaction and the molecular targets of natural repellents. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The current study provides a detailed description of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for the estimation of the basic reproductive number R0 and the rate of viral production. We also provide a mathematical analysis of the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to viral clearance. Our results can be used to guide the development of effective antiviral therapies and to inform the design of clinical trials. This work can also be used to guide the development of mathematical models for the spread of ZIKV. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is triggered by environmental stressors such as warming and nutrient enrichment. However, the underlying processes are still not fully understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release is a consequence of the metabolic stress and the resulting amino acid catabolism. The resulting increase in ammonium release is a key factor in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, as it promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. This process is a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. In the absence of tumors, the epithelium regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. Here, we show that the loss of tumors leads to a dysbiotic microbiome and intestinal barrier dysfunction. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate the balance between host and microbial homeostasis and tumorigenesis. It also provides a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors. This work may also have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to treat intestinal tumors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the second leading cause of cancer death in women. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, and the response to chemotherapy is a major determinant of the outcome of the disease. In this study, we show that the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1 is required for the development of breast cancer, and that targeting these pathways may improve the response to chemotherapy. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer.

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is one of the most important questions in the history of the Earth system. We show that the start of accelerated deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a strong climate response. This finding has implications for the interpretation of the timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere and for the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the climate system. It also provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can have a strong impact on climate. (Less)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries and biodiversity. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. View Full-Text

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material are responsible for the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, this ability is lost, and the few remaining regenerative neurons are unable to repair damage. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery provides a unique platform for the discovery of novel factors that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Moreover, our study reveals a previously unknown form of activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the adult CNS, which may be a powerful platform for the discovery of factors that control this process. Together, these findings provide new insights into the control of the adult nervous system’s regenerative capacity.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in a flowering plant, which is a major step toward understanding the evolution of this process. We find that the distribution of recombination in plants is similar to that in animals, suggesting that the process of recombination has been conserved over a long period of evolution.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the human brain is organized in functionally distinct networks, which are active during rest and deactive during task. This hypothesis has been validated in healthy subjects, but the RSN organization in disease populations has not been studied. Here, we used metabolic PET to identify and validate RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the DMN, but that this RSN was subordinated in PD. In addition, we found that the dominant RSN was deactive during rest and task, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study provides a new perspective on the organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated. In bacteria, a second type of RNA, the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA, is found on subsets of mRNAs. This work shows that a similar modification is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial mRNAs in yeast. The 5′ NAD+ cap may have a role in regulating translation of specific classes of mRNA.

The persistence of epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes is a novel finding. The results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. The findings also suggest that epigenetic alterations at specific loci may be a biomarker for the identification of individuals who will benefit from intensive therapy. These results may also have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes.

The role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Graphical abstract:

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease, which is characterized by a high mortality rate. The present study shows that gut permeability is increased in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the disease and in the regulation of the psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of new therapeutic strategies for this disease.

The production of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit is essential for the development of a distinctive aroma, but the biosynthetic pathways of these compounds are unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the final products. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato aroma and lays the foundation for the development of improved cultivars. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the context of climate change. Here we show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of climate change in the context of biodiversity loss, and they suggest that the additional impacts of warming may be more severe than previously thought. This work provides a framework for understanding the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning, and it has implications for the management of biodiversity and the design of climate change mitigation policies.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for spatial navigation, are anatomically segregated from other cell types, and that they exhibit strong coupling among themselves but weaker coupling to other cell types. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and its functional subdivisions, which will help to elucidate the neural basis of navigation. This work also provides a platform for future studies of the neural basis of other cognitive and sensory functions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of environmental and developmental cues. In this study, we show that the FT gene in dodder C. australis does not function in the regulation of flowering. Instead, we demonstrate that the FT protein is able to move from the host to the parasite, where it is able to induce flowering. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of a flowering signal moving between hosts and parasites. The results of this study may help to understand the evolution of flowering and flowering regulation. They may also help to understand the evolution of parasitism.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The cause of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-producing cells and a reduction in the number of dopamine-containing neurons in the striatum, the region of the brain that receives dopamine from the substantia nigra and is responsible for the motor symptoms of the disease. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of striatonigral fibers that are part of the dopamine-producing system of the brain. These fibers are part of a system of cells and fibers that are likely to be affected in the disease. We suggest that this system is important for the control of movement and motivation. Understanding the role of this system in health and disease could lead to the development of new treatments for Parkinson’s disease.

We all know when we’re feeling connected to someone, but how do we know when two people are feeling connected to each other? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for setting the heart rate, and their automaticity is essential for the normal function of the heart. However, the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN automaticity are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN automaticity. We show that STIM1 is expressed in SANCs and is required for the normal function of the SAN. Our results reveal that STIM1 regulates SAN automaticity by controlling the content of Ca2+ stores in SANCs. These studies provide insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN automaticity and may lead to the development of new therapies for cardiac arrhythmia. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote rice resistance against insect herbivores. This study provides a new perspective on the role of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages and for the expression of inflammatory mediators. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the adaptive modulation of neuronal firing rates. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants with DNA nanostructures and show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work also provides a platform for future studies on the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

The coastal zone is a critical ecosystem that supports a wide range of valuable goods and services. However, it is also the most vulnerable to the impacts of nutrient pollution. In this study, we show that small tributaries can be a significant source of coastal nutrient pollution. Our findings have important implications for coastal management, as they suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries, which are often overlooked in current efforts. Our study also highlights the importance of small tributaries in the Anthropocene, as they are the primary source of nutrient pollution in many watersheds. This work provides a unique snapshot of coastal nutrient inputs from a large lake, and it can be used to inform future efforts to understand and manage coastal eutrophication.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is made available to the system only in rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “rare event” dynamics of statistical physics, and we propose a simple model that captures the essential features of the observed behavior. Our results suggest that the rare event dynamics of chemical networks may be a general feature of complex systems that are made available to external forces only in rare combinations.

The role of the brain’s electrical activity in the genesis of seizures is well established. However, the mechanisms by which the electrical activity of the brain can predispose to seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of an autoimmune antibody against a specific type of glutamate receptor can change the electrical activity of the brain. We show that this change in electrical activity can predispose the brain to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer insights into the mechanisms by which the electrical activity of the brain can predispose to seizures. They also suggest that the electrical activity of the brain may be a useful biomarker for the presence of autoimmune encephalitis. This could have important implications for the diagnosis and treatment of this disease.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of our understanding of the Earth system. However, the history of C-perturbed events is still poorly understood. Here, we present a new approach to study a C-perturbed event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was part of a global warming event that was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and anoxia. This study provides a new perspective on the history of abrupt climate change and the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of deforestation-prone tropical peatlands in the world. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification body, and its certification is often required by major corporations and countries. However, the impact of RSPO certification on deforestation has not been evaluated. We show that RSPO certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation from 9.8 to 6.6% y−1. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is a large protein complex involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 14 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

The evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study in developmental biology. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes, but in many other species, sex is determined by multiple interacting loci, resulting in more than two sexes. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a species with four possible sex classes. We find that the interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation results in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the acquisition of a new sex determination allele can create additional axes of variation for varied traits. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of multiple interacting sex determination alleles. (Show more)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and photodecomposing species that are generated by the action of light on the retinal pigment epithelium. The retina is also challenged by the presence of iron, which is a key component of the Fenton chemistry that generates these reactive species. We show that the presence of iron in the retina promotes the oxidation and degradation of a class of molecules that are present in the retina as a result of the action of light on the retina. These findings have implications for the understanding of the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (Show more)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key topic in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophore predators have evolved a modular feeding strategy, and that the evolution of the tentacles is linked to the evolution of prey type. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. This work contributes to the understanding of the evolution of predator specialization, and to the broader topic of predator diversification.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The study of the hand is complicated by the fact that the hand is the most mobile part of the body and, therefore, the most difficult to preserve in the fossil record. We present the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of the human hand and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and the evolution of the genus Homo. It also has implications for the evolution of the human lineage and the origin of modern human behavior. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic target. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and show that they are effective in vitro and in vivo. We also show that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of B-cell lymphoma, and a target for the treatment of this disease.

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This is a relatively new field of research, and we hope that this study will encourage others to use this approach to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This will help to inform policy makers and practitioners about the importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets.

The agricultural revolution has been accompanied by the development of farm machinery, which has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
